awd_titl_txt: 2017 EFRI ACQUIRE Grantees Meeting, San Jose, May 14, 2017
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal requests funds for the "2017 EFRI ACQUIRE Grantees Meeting",the first annual meeting for the NSF-funded Advancing Communication and Quantum Information Research in Engineering (ACQUIRE) program. It will be held, this year, on May 14, 2017 at the San Jose Convention Center, San Jose, California, United States. The goal of this one-day grantees meeting is to review current grantees research progress, hear about latest international research progress in this area, discuss future research opportunities and challenges in a workshop-like environment through breakout sessions, and provide feedback to ACQUIRE researchers. The support requested in this grant will be distributed to invited speakers and students to partially defray travel costs, and to help cover a portion of other key logistical and organizational costs. This meeting provides an opportunity for grantees students to make poster presentations to, and get feedback from reviewers, ACQUIRE PI's and plenary invited speakers. The workshop will provide inter-disciplinary interactions between engineering and physics disciplines for enabling student participation and learning opportunities. 


The intellectual merit of this one-day grantees meeting is to review current grantees research progress, discuss future research in the ACQUIRE program, and provide feedback. Engineering and physics researchers are confronting major challenges in a four-year quest to engineer micro-scale quantum communication system components for large-scale networks. The challenging goal is to create a compact and practical quantum communication technology operating near room temperature with low energy in a fiber optic network with entangled photons. A diverse range of topics and techniques are being investigated, including sources, detectors, up-converters, quantum memories, synchronizers, error correctors, etc. with various material platforms. This annual grantees meeting offers an opportunity for recommendations for the ACQUIRE program and future growth of the related and broader topics of quantum optical communications research, and secure optical communications with key researchers and decision makers from academia, industry, government laboratories and funding agencies.

In terms of educational aspects, this meeting provides an opportunity for grantees students to make poster presentations to, and get feedback from reviewers, ACQUIRE PI's and plenary invited speakers who represent the broad international diversity of this topic. Students will benefit and learn from attending and scribing focused breakout session discussions. Students will benefit from discussions involving different perspectives ranging from university experts and industry scientists, and be exposed to diverse aspects of quantum optical communications which bridge traditional physics and engineering disciplines.

por.por_cntn:
The 2017 EFRI ACQUIRE Grantees Meeting was the first of five planned annual meetings for the NSF-funded Advancing Communication and Quantum Information Research in Engineering (ACQUIRE) program. It was held in conjunction with the Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics (CLEO) on May 14 at the San Jose Convention Center, San Jose, California, United States. The main goal of this meeting was to discuss the progress of quantum optical communications research among the ACQUIRE teams, and discuss future plans. The workshop gathered 53 attendees including 29 graduate students.

At the Annual Workshop six funded teams presented year 1 (ongoing) results and progress, and discussed challenges and opportunities. The participants voiced that the workshop was a much-needed opportunity to share information and calibrate where other researchers are at this early stage of the NSF ACQUIRE program. The presentations from the invited experts were highly valued, and additional time was requested for such interactions in future meetings.  

According to the Principal Investigators, the following advancements appear promising as potentially transformative outcomes of ACQUIRE research:

  • Integrated optics technology, using materials platforms such as silicon, silicon carbide, aluminum nitride, lithium niobate and diamond, is being used to develop photon sources integrated with other components such as pump lasers, filters, couplers, and switches. The heralding efficiency for spontaneous sources is being improved via time and frequency multiplexing. The performance of triggered single-photon sources is being improved through materials and nanofabrication.
  • Quantum memories based on color centers in diamond and other solid-state materials, and atomic memories in gases are being studied. A variety of photonic structures that can enhance light-memory coupling have been designed and fabricated. Frequency conversion devices are being demonstrated in several of the aforementioned materials platforms. These components may lead to an integrated quantum repeater, which would be useful for both quantum communications and computing.  
  • Quantum optical communication links have been built, error correction codes for memories are being developed, and novel protocols that enhance the bit-rate performance (e.g., of MDI-QKD) have been demonstrated in the laboratory, but not yet using integrated optics.  

Research discussed at this meeting addressed one of NSF’s 10 Big Ideas, “The Quantum Leap: Leading the Next Quantum Revolution”. The meeting brought researchers, experts and program reviewers together to discuss research and education findings with scholars and students from other teams, and to provide feedback to researchers. The workshop format allowed graduate students exposure to interdisciplinary learning in electrical engineering, physics and materials science, through research presentations, invited-speaker lectures, breakout sessions, poster presentations and discussions. This workshop’s best poster prizes were presented to: Chaitali Joshi, Columbia University; Xiang Guo, Yale University; Bin Fang, Univ. of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign; and Alp Sipahigil, Harvard University.
